title: Assignment 1 Instructions
text: Due Date: 2/25/26 (FLEX to 3/4/26)

title: Assignment 1 Instructions
section: Step 0: Choose one or two Visualizations to Recreate
text:
Step 0: Choose one or two Visualizations to Recreate

Browse the set of provided visualizations and datasets
  
.Each vis is accompanied by the dataset used to create it. Select one or two visualizations to attempt to recreate.

Familiarize yourself with the dataset and its structure. Do some exploring on the Data to Viz 
  
 site to learn common vis names, caveats, and some tips to create them. As a hint, I have put the chart name in brackets for each image (though sometimes names will differ!)

Decide whether you will use AI or not ‚Äì if you use it, be sure to include the link in your submission

title: Assignment 1 Instructions
section: Step 1: Recreate the vis with your chosen tool
text:
Step 1: Recreate the vis with your chosen tool

First, choose an appropriate tool for your chosen vis from the list of approved tools below. You can change your mind at any time.







  
  Holoviz Panel



  
  Manim



  
  Unreal Engine



  
  CosmoGraph



  
  Bokeh



  
  Vega-Lite



  
  Gephi



  
  Seaborn



  
  Folium



  
  Plotly



  
  MATLAB



  
  Shiny



  
  D3.js



  
  Matplotlib



  
  Blender



  
  QGIS



  
  Google Charts



  
  VisIt



  
  OpenGL



  
  VTK



  
  Unity



  
  Orange





Next, load and prepare the dataset.






Note



The dataset may require preprocessing (e.g., filtering, cleaning, or restructuring) to match the visual representation in the original image. You should document any changes you make to the dataset to recreate the visualization. You can add auxiliary data as needed, but don‚Äôt forget to cite and document it!








TipFAQs




 Do we have to write code to stream the data from the Google Docs link? 



Write some code to recreate the visualization(s) as accurately as you can






TipFAQs




 Do I need to try and replicate even the little icons and shapes? 
 Do we have to match the colors too? 
 What if I can‚Äôt get an exact 1:1 replica?



Write a step-by-step breakdown of how you created each visualization (for eample, any data cleaning or transformation required, how to change the formatting to match the original, how to add text and/or annotations, etc.).
You can do this by choosing one or more of these options:

(preferred option) Interspersing markdown cells with your code cells in notebook environments, such as Colab, Jupyter, Observable, R, Matlab. Also export to .pdf if possible.

Use Quarto to intersperse text and code (node you‚Äôll still need to upload the runnable code)

Including block comments in your code, and line comments as well (ok option, but gets hard to read fast)

Screenshotting code snippets and putting them into a word doc interspersed with text (not recommended, but you do you)

Narrating a screen-capture video of you writing the code while explaining what you‚Äôre doing. Be sure to include closed captions/subtitles (great choice if you don‚Äôt like fiddling with documents)

Your documentation should be clear enough that another student could follow your steps and recreate your visualization without prior knowledge of the data or tool.






TipFAQs




 If I choose the video option, can I use AI to generate the narration? 
 How beautiful does my code need to be?

title: Assignment 1 Instructions
section: Step 2: Add a descriptive caption to your vis
text:
Step 2: Add a descriptive caption to your vis
Add a caption summarizing the visualization‚Äôs purpose and encodings. Check out this resource 
  
 for how to write great captions.

Some vis tools have built-in functionality for creating captions, others don‚Äôt. If you choose a tool that doesn‚Äôt, find a workaround, and then you can mention how annoying it was to have to do that in your reflection üòÄ.







Note



Captions are more than just titles! They should be able to stand alone if taken out of context, succinctly describing the main points the viewer should take away from looking at this image: What is being shown? What are the salient features? What task or analysis question can be completed or addressed by this vis?

title: Assignment 1 Instructions
text:
Step 3: Reflection






Important



Please type in the Google Assignent doc provided on Blackboard, don‚Äôt copy paste from another doc, or it will get flagged as plagiarism by the system! Also pls no AI


As you‚Äôre working, take some time to reflect and write some short notes about:

Which tools did you consider, and which did you end up choosing to use, and why?

What challenges did you encounter in replicating the visualization?

Did you have to modify the dataset in any way to get the desired output?

Which features of your tool helped or hindered the recreation process (strengths/limitations)?

Are there elements of the original visualization that were difficult or impossible to replicate? If so, why?

What is one piece of advice you would give someone wanting to use this tool?

If you had to do this again, would you choose the same tool? Why or why not?

Write your reflection via Blackboard under Assignment 1 Part 2, then don‚Äôt forget to press ‚ú®Submit ‚ú®






TipFAQs




 Are bullets fine for my reflection, or do you want a full essay?

title: Assignment 1 Instructions
text:
Originality Checks
The following checks will be performed for each submission; If any of these validation conditions are not satisfied, your assignment will be returned to you with or without options for remediation:

Ensure that your recreated visualization was generated from the dataset, not simply redrawn in Canva or other drawing program. - Please refer to the syllabus for the course policy on Academic Misconduct

AI Policy must be followed, including a link to the chat

Responses to reflection questions must be specific to your experience ‚Äì generic AI-generated answers will be flagged.

title: Assignment 1 Instructions
text:
Timeliness
Requests for extensions must be made to the Professor before the assignment due date and time (by 9 pm).

title: About
text: This is an alpha test of trying to rely less on blackboard because it infuriates me. Seriously the rage I feel when interacting with BB is beyond compare.

title: Phase 0: Individual Project Pitch
text: Due Date: 2/16/26

title: Phase 0: Individual Project Pitch
text:
1. Identify the domain (subject area)
Use an appropriate amount of specificity.









Tip‚úÖ Good examples of domains




Explainable AI
Healthcare economics
Social network analysis











Warning‚ùåBad examples of domains




Machine Learning (too broad)
Minor 7th dominant cords in Bach symphonies (too specific)
Data visualization (too meta)

title: Phase 0: Individual Project Pitch
section: 2. Describe a target user of your vis
text:
2. Describe a target user of your vis
Use objective observables to describe them that relate to the task (check Chapter 3).









Tip‚úÖ Good examples of users




Consumer with a fitness tracker
A potential voter

Venture capitalist











Warning‚ùå Bad examples of users




Myself and/or my friends
Someone that doesn‚Äôt understand the data
The professor grading this vis

title: Phase 0: Individual Project Pitch
text:
3. Describe the main task(s)
These could be action/target pairs or analysis question(s) the user of your vis would need to do (check Chapter 3).









Tip‚úÖ Good examples of tasks




Determine how object size affects semantic segmentation boundaries
Cluster Goodreads users based on book genre and recommendations
Explore the narrative structure of popular Manga











Warning‚ùå Bad examples of tasks




To understand the data
To learn about Chemistry

title: Phase 0: Individual Project Pitch
text:
4. Identify one or more datasets
These can be exemplars; you are not locked in. Make sure the dataset is available, documented, and of good quality.









Tip‚úÖ Good examples of datasets




Bird Migration Data (data was used for a published paper, documentation exists, readable .csv format)
Cityscapes Dataset (benchmark dataset used for many CV/AI/ML papers, lots of code available on internet to process)
Iris Dataset (another canonical dataset, straight from an academic lab)











Warning‚ùå Bad examples of datasets




We will scrape Instagram (you probably won‚Äôt have time, data will be messy)
We will collect a survey about people‚Äôs habits (designing a good survey is super tricky, takes time)
We will request Twitter/X API developer access to collect Tweets (again, no time)
Anything like this: test.csv

title: Phase 0: Individual Project Pitch
section: 5. Find, link, and briefly describe related work
text:
5. Find, link, and briefly describe related work
These should be a few related visualizations you‚Äôve come across while looking into this area. You may want to consider how might a different kind of visualization reveal new insights?
Related work can be ‚Äúrelated‚Äù by being similar in the What-Why-How framework (Chapter 1,2,3) in any of these ways:






TipWays that related work can be related




Same/similar domain
Same/similar dataset type/semantics (Chapter 2)
Similar tasks & target user (Chapter 3)
Similar vis type/idiom (Chapter 5, Chapter 7, Chapter 8, Chapter 9)
Similar interaction mechanisms (Chapter 11-14)



You can use any visual you find on the internet or in print, but you must be able to trace it back to the original source and cite it.

title: Phase 0: Individual Project Pitch
text:
Perusing Classmates‚Äô Pitches
I recommend reading through your classmates‚Äô pitches and engaging by asking questions, reacting with thumbs up, or just mentioning that you like the idea because it sounds cool. Maybe as you surf you will have your own idea sparked anew.

title: Phase 0: Individual Project Pitch
text:
Originality Checks
The following checks will be performed for each submission; If any of these validation conditions are not satisfied, your assignment will be returned to you with or without options for remediation:

Check for plagiarism/crappy AI copypaste - Please refer to the syllabus for the course policy on Academic Misconduct

Check for no cited sources - You will be notified and asked to resubmit with the required citations within 1 day of notification, otherwise the Late Policy applies

title: Phase 0: Individual Project Pitch
text:
Rubric


Grading Rubric








Complete
Not Complete




Pitch contains domain




Pitch contains task/analysis questions




Pitch contains user description




Pitch contains dataset, which is cited




Pitch contains related works and links




Instructions followed for posting

title: Group Project Proposal + Group Charter (Phase 1)
text: Due Date: 3/2/26

title: Group Project Proposal + Group Charter (Phase 1)
section: 1. Expected technical roles of each team member
text:
1. Expected technical roles of each team member
Every group must account for the 5 functional roles in some way.

Assign the baseline roles (Code Monkey, Project Manager, Technical Communictions Manager) of each member. Every team member should have 1 of these roles. You can define new ones, but use the given roles as a guide.
Decide how you will dole out the additional Auxiliary Roles (QA/QC, Resource Manager). For example, you can rotate them for each deliverable, or pick one person who will manage it for the whole project.







WarningFAQs




 Can we switch roles during the project? 
 How many code monkeys do we need?

title: Group Project Proposal + Group Charter (Phase 1)
text:
2. Scheduling

Indicate a weekly outside-class meeting time slot, during which everyone agrees they could be free to meet. You don‚Äôt need to always meet at this time, but make sure that there exists at least one weekly time in our space-time continuum that works for everyone. This is required.

Discuss whether anyone has any foreseeable schedule disruptions that might affect the team (conference travel, on-site job interviews, part/full time work, midterm exams). You don‚Äôt need to divulge your personal life circumstances, just let your team know if you anticipate being away at a certain time, and how you‚Äôll stay on top of your work.







WarningFAQs




 How often do we actually need to meet?

title: Group Project Proposal + Group Charter (Phase 1)
text:
3. Conflict resolution strategies

What should the procedure be for students that consistently display a pattern of not completing work?
How will your group use AI in the project? Some people prefer never to use it, others rely heavily on it. Come up with a compromise that everyone is comfortable with, if possible.







WarningFAQs




 What if group members disagree about AI usage? 
 What should we do if a member isn‚Äôt contributing?

title: Group Project Proposal + Group Charter (Phase 1)
text:
4. Collaboration tool preferences
Briefly discuss and settle on what tools you will use for which aspects. Ask the Professor for recommendations if needed.

For coding you may want to use Github, Colab, or Observable HQ. Whatever you choose needs to have version control and collaboration capabilities.
What will you use for project management?







TipIdeas for project management tools






Trello, here is an example Trello board setup
a Google Doc for task assignments/meeting minutes
Jira





What will you use for brainstorming? You‚Äôll use Google Docs for Phase 1 and 2, but you may want to use something else for brainstorming after that, or keep writing in the same doc for simplicity.







TipIdeas for visual brainstorming tools





Padlet, FigJam, Miro, mural.co are my favorites




What will you use for creating your interrim deliverables (group presentations)? Consider whether it would be best to have interactive elements.







TipIdeas for interactive presentations





For interactive html-based presentations reveal.js, slidev or Quarto for open source options, or Prezi (I‚Äôve not heard good things about this one from past students). Canva is also an option but it costs money.









WarningFAQs




 Do we have to use specific tools?

title: Group Project Proposal + Group Charter (Phase 1)
text:
5. Communication preferences & plans
For example, do most people in the group prefer email, Discord, in-person? Will you exchange numbers/WhatsApp? For virtual meetings, will you use the Discord voice channel, Google Meet, etc? For in person meetings, where is a good spot? Who will take the meeting minutes? Discuss as a team what time people go to bed and wake up, and respect each others‚Äô work/life balance.

title: Group Project Proposal + Group Charter (Phase 1)
text:
1. Domain and Project Motivation
What is the Big Idea for your Project? What is the domain, who are your target users, and what tasks/analysis questions should they be able to complete with your project?






Tip





To determine these questions, do a quick internet search like you did for your Pitch to see what‚Äôs currently being done. You‚Äôll have a chance to refine these ideas further. A great place to discover un-solved tasks in a vis area is to check ‚ÄúFuture Work‚Äù sections of peer-reviewed publications.



When describing your analysis questions/tasks, be sure to use the concepts from Chapters 2 & 3 (Data Abstraction, Task Abstraction) in the textbook to write good tasks that are appropriate to the data types and dataset types you have identified. At least one of your analysis questions/tasks should require deriving new data/transforming data.

title: Group Project Proposal + Group Charter (Phase 1)
text:
2. Data
Identify one or more preliminary dataset(s) that would support the tasks you identify.






Important



Be sure to cite your dataset.



Dataset requirements
Your dataset should be rich enough to support multiple analysis tasks and meaningful visual encodings. Very simple two- or three- column tables typically only support a single chart type and do not provide enough structure for a semester-long project.
Datasets with only two attributes will not be approved unless you justify why the structure is inherently complex (e.g., network edges, text corpora, spatial geometries). You can also add auxiliary data (for example, adding spatial boundaries from a 2nd source to categorical place names in a simple 2-column dataset dataset).


Detail the types, semantics, and limitations

For each attribute you plan to use, include a description of the data type(s) and the semantics of the attributes (putting this information in a table in your doc might be good for this).







NoteReminders





Attribute semantics are the real-world meaning of that attribute. A dataset can have multiple types; which you choose is a design choice.




Additionally, mention some limitations of the dataset(s). A limitation is anything about the data that could affect the analysis or conclusions. Examples include:



Size and Access

Dataset too large to store
Can only be streamed via API


Coverage and Granularity

Only includes one country, platform, or time period

Missing certain populations or categories
Lacks geographic detail
Aggregated at too course resolution for the task


Missing or Noisy Values

Many nulls or nans
Inconsistent categories or labels


Provenance

Unknown data collection and processing methods
Insufficient or dubious documentation



If you choose from the above list, or find a different limitation, explain how this limitation might affect your user‚Äôs ability to complete the task(s).






WarningFAQs




 What counts as having ‚Äúaccess‚Äù to the data? 
 Can we use multiple datasets?

title: Group Project Proposal + Group Charter (Phase 1)
text:
3. Project Final Form

Include some info about the end product you might want to create







TipFinal form inspiration examples!






Animated map
Large-format poster
Data quilt
Story Map
VR experience or XR experience
Scrollytelling data story
Interactive website
something else?





Start thinking about software tools could be used to create your final vision, ideas for specific encodings/idioms, user interface/interaction, and any issues you foresee.







WarningFAQs




 Do we need to decide on our final format now?
 What if we forsee no issues?

title: Group Project Proposal + Group Charter (Phase 1)
text:
Originality Checks
The following checks will be performed for each submission; If any of these validation conditions are not satisfied, your assignment will be returned to your group with or without options for remediation:

Check for plagiarism via SafeAssign and by eye - Please refer to the syllabus for the course policy on Academic Misconduct
Check for no cited sources (including your dataset) - You will be notified and asked to resubmit with the required citations within 1 day of notification, otherwise the Late Policy applies
Check that any images are either original or have correct attribution - Please refer to the syllabus for the course policy on Academic Misconduct

title: Group Project Proposal + Group Charter (Phase 1)
text:
Timeliness
Late policy for Group Work = -25% penalty per day (i.e.¬†NOT compounded; 0% credit is available after four days). Requests for extensions must be made to and approved by the Professor, via email, before 9 pm on the day the assignment is due.

title: Home
text:
This is stuff for Dr.¬†Williams‚Äô section of Data Visualization (CMSC 436 and 636).
Here is the syllabus








This is a Quarto website.
To learn more about Quarto websites visit https://quarto.org/docs/websites. You may want to use it for your group project! You can embed reactive apps in it, see the Shinylive demo for an example.
